keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army on corruption charges, the most senior officers purged in a sweeping anti-corruption campaign initiated in 2023.
He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general, is also a former member of the Politburo, the second-highest echelon of China’s ruling party, making his expulsion a significant political move.

The removals are part of President Xi Jinping’s broader 'cleaning house' strategy, with implications for reshaping the Central Military Commission and the Central Committee’s leadership ahead of the upcoming Fourth Plenum.

He Weidong has close ties to Xi Jinping, including overlapping service in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s, and played a key role in planning aggressive military drills around Taiwan after U.S. political actions in 2022.
The purge includes seven other senior officials, many of whom were absent from public view for months, suggesting a coordinated internal audit and disciplinary process.
The actions reflect a broader trend of political and military restructuring under Xi, emphasizing accountability and central control within the military and party leadership.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army on corruption charges, marking a major development in China’s anti-corruption campaign that began in 2023. He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general and former member of the Politburo, is the first sitting general expelled from the Central Military Commission since the Cultural Revolution and is seen as a close associate of President Xi Jinping, with historical ties to Fujian and Zhejiang provinces. His removal, along with others including Miao Hua, former Eastern Theatre Command commander Lin Xiangyang, and several political commissars, reflects a broader political restructuring under Xi Jinping’s 'cleaning house' initiative. The expulsions are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum, and the actions signal a shift in military leadership, especially in response to heightened tensions with Taiwan and U.S. political actions like Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taipei in 2022. These decisions not only reinforce internal party discipline but also have global implications, as they reflect China’s efforts to centralize power and maintain strategic control over military and political affairs.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
